name: Halley's Comet
description: Halley's Comet is the most famous comet, visible from Earth every 75-76 years. It is the only short-period comet that is visible to the naked eye from Earth and will next appear in 2061.
funFacts: Halley's Comet has been observed since 240 BC.
The comet was named after Edmond Halley who predicted its return.
Its next appearance will be in July 2061.
The Giotto spacecraft flew through its tail in 1986.

name: Comet Hale-Bopp
description: Hale-Bopp was one of the most widely observed comets of the 20th century. It was visible to the naked eye for a record 18 months and is one of the largest comets ever observed.
funFacts: Hale-Bopp was visible to the naked eye for 18 months.
It has one of the largest known comet nuclei.
Discovered independently by two amateur astronomers.
It won't return until around the year 4530.

name: Comet 67P
description: Comet 67P is famous for being the target of ESA's Rosetta mission, which included the first soft landing on a comet nucleus by the Philae lander in 2014.
funFacts: Philae lander was first spacecraft to land on a comet.
The comet has a distinctive 'rubber duck' shape.
Rosetta orbited the comet for over two years.
Water vapor was detected in the comet's coma.

name: Comet NEOWISE
description: Comet NEOWISE was one of the brightest comets in the northern hemisphere since Hale-Bopp. It became visible to the naked eye in July 2020.
funFacts: NEOWISE was the brightest comet since Hale-Bopp for northern observers.
Discovered by the NEOWISE space telescope in March 2020.
The comet won't return for nearly 7,000 years.
It passed closest to Earth on July 23, 2020.

name: Comet Encke
description: Comet Encke has the shortest orbital period of any known comet. It is the parent body of the Taurid meteor shower.
funFacts: Encke has the shortest period of any known comet at 3.3 years.
It was the second periodic comet to be recognized (after Halley).
The Taurid meteor shower comes from Encke's debris.
Its orbital period is decreasing due to outgassing.

name: Comet Wild 2
description: Comet Wild 2 was the target of NASA's Stardust mission, which collected samples from the comet's coma and returned them to Earth in 2006.
funFacts: Stardust returned the first comet samples to Earth.
The nucleus has a distinctive pockmarked surface.
Analysis revealed pre-solar grains older than our solar system.
The comet's current orbit was altered by Jupiter in 1974.

name: Comet Shoemaker-Levy 9
description: Shoemaker-Levy 9 collided with Jupiter in July 1994, marking the first direct observation of an extraterrestrial collision. The comet broke into 21 visible fragments.
funFacts: First comet observed impacting a planet.
Jupiter's gravity broke it into 21 pieces before impact.
The impacts left scars on Jupiter larger than Earth.
The collision was watched by telescopes worldwide.
discoveredBy: Carolyn and Eugene Shoemaker, David Levy

name: Comet Tempel 1
description: Comet Tempel 1 was the target of NASA's Deep Impact mission, which deliberately crashed an impactor into the comet to study its interior composition.
funFacts: Deep Impact mission crashed a probe into Tempel 1 in 2005.
The impact released material from beneath the surface.
The comet was later visited again by the Stardust mission.
It has a potato-like shape with a layered structure.
